content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "REVERSE" option has therefore been deactivated.
I believe you are missing something in the stub. The second input line "N integers separated by spaces" is not present. Other than that, looks great.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very good puzzle, gonna be pretty hard to figure out in reverse mode, but that makes it fun.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: J'accepte car j'aime beaucoup ce genre de clash , il est ideal pour les mode reverse et plus rapide je l'ai testé.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Super-fun problem! While I do think it's manageable in reverse mode‒once the eye catches the pattern of _ and /\, it's easy enough to make the leap to binary‒it'd be great to see it in the other modes as well, but that's up to you.

Love this problem! It's so cool that such simple transformations can create such interesting results. Unfortunately, I can't seem to come up with a solution that passes your test cases. :/

I fought with it for a while before giving up and checking how you did it, and I think there's a bug in your solution that must also have been present when you generated the expected outputs.

On Line 8, you have `k=i[0]+i[1]`; this grabs the first and second digits for the 01 -> $@ transformation, but the problem statement says to perform this operation on the first and *last* digit, not the second.

Please let me know if the issue is in my understanding of the problem rather than your code. Either way, looking forward to approving this one once that mystery is solved. :)
Oh I'm sorry for that. I will rectify it. Thanks a lot for that comment. It was meant to be k=i[0]+i[-1]. I will rectify it. I apologize for it again.
Sure, @Allis, I will add it in other modes as well.
Thanks @pindsz. I am new to contribution. I don't know how to write a stub to do something like a=list(map(int, input().split())). I apologize for that.

The best we can do is `loopline x n:int`. It generates some pretty unidiomatic code, but that's the nature of trying to make it language-agnostic. I think most people will probably just delete it and write something more like your suggestion, but it does make sense for the stub to match the input format.
Thanks @Allis. I will add it now.

I was thinking about this, and while I definitely feel it's tractable, I wonder whether making it two underscores per 1 instead of just one (such that the outputs all have the same width) would make it a little more obvious that the binary representations need to be padded in order to solve the puzzle.

I agree with you, or making the /\ symbol a single symbole like # 
because when playing reverse mode, realizing that  /\ is considerded a single symbole is gonna be really hard.

Thanks for handling that so quickly! Alas, it looks like that may not be the only issue. On Line 7, you've got `i[::-1]`, which simply reverses the bits; the problem statement leads me to believe that should be something like `i[1:-1]` to grab all but the first and last digits on which to do the hill transformations.

Again, I may have the wrong of it, but if I make that adjustment to your program, its outputs start to match mine. :)
Thanks a lot @Allis. I have rectified it. I have also added some comments to let know what is going on in the program.
Thanks for being so receptive to feedback, and also for the excellent puzzle.
